conclusion: Analyzing the velocity-time graphs to determine if displacements are the same.
Understanding the graph: vertical axis represents velocity, horizontal axis represents time.
Car A's velocity starts at v₁ and increases to v₂; Car B's velocity starts at v₂ and decreases to v₁.
Both cars are traveling in the same direction on a straight highway.
Displacement equals the area under the velocity-time curve: Displacement = ∫ v(t) dt.
Car A displacement equals the area under curve A from t=0 to t=t₁.
Car B displacement equals the area under curve B from t=0 to t=t₁.
Total area of rectangle bounded by v=0, v=v₂, t=0, and t=t₁ is v₂·t₁; both curves fill this rectangle.
Average velocity of Car A is (v₁ + v₂)/2; Average velocity of Car B is (v₂ + v₁)/2; these are equal.
Area under each curve represents displacement; both curves are symmetric, area equals (v₁ + v₂)·t₁/2.
Final answer: Yes, displacements of Car A and Car B are the same during the period from t=0 to t=t₁.
Both cars have the same average velocity and travel for the same time period.
Both cars have the same displacement, which equals (v₁ + v₂)·t₁/2.
One car speeding up while the other slowing down doesn't change total distance when initial and final velocities are opposites.
